list.name: Changes
list.comment:
Refactor db-easy structure and enhance functionality
Reorganized db-easy modules: extracted constants, restructured adapter implementations, and added missing dependencies. Updated package metadata and scripts for clarity. These changes improve modularity, maintainability, and functionality of the library.

task.summary:
Add initial implementation of db-easy schema migration tool
Introduces CLI, configuration handling, SQL parsing, templating, and execution logic for schema migrations. Includes support for PostgreSQL, MSSQL, and MariaDB through adapter-based architecture, and integrates with Jinja2 for SQL template rendering.

Refactor database synchronization to use adapter locking.
Replaced direct database access logic with an adapter-based approach to manage schema synchronization. Added table locking mechanisms to prevent concurrent runs. Updated `Config` class and related structures to support improved workflows.

Add flexible database connection and configuration options
Refactored CLI and config parsing to support granular database connection parameters such as host, port, instance, username, and password. Introduced support for default schema, and made log/lock table creation schema-aware. Enhanced checksum verification and error handling in the database synchronization process.

Simplify default port handling in configuration.
Removed the fallback default port assignment of 5432 to ensure the configuration explicitly provides all necessary values. This change enforces stricter validation and avoids unintended defaults.

Implement ordered SQL processing by directory structure
Introduce deterministic processing for SQL files based on a predefined directory order (`ORDERED_DIRS`) to ensure execution respects dependencies. The remaining directories are processed alphabetically to handle any additional structures. This change enhances safety and predictability in SQL execution workflows.

Refactor db-easy structure and enhance functionality
Reorganized db-easy modules: extracted constants, restructured adapter implementations, and added missing dependencies. Updated package metadata and scripts for clarity. These changes improve modularity, maintainability, and functionality of the library.

Add initial implementation of db-easy schema migration tool
Introduces CLI, configuration handling, SQL parsing, templating, and execution logic for schema migrations. Includes support for PostgreSQL, MSSQL, and MariaDB through adapter-based architecture, and integrates with Jinja2 for SQL template rendering.

Refactor database synchronization to use adapter locking.
Replaced direct database access logic with an adapter-based approach to manage schema synchronization. Added table locking mechanisms to prevent concurrent runs. Updated `Config` class and related structures to support improved workflows.

Add flexible database connection and configuration options
Refactored CLI and config parsing to support granular database connection parameters such as host, port, instance, username, and password. Introduced support for default schema, and made log/lock table creation schema-aware. Enhanced checksum verification and error handling in the database synchronization process.

Simplify default port handling in configuration.
Removed the fallback default port assignment of 5432 to ensure the configuration explicitly provides all necessary values. This change enforces stricter validation and avoids unintended defaults.

Implement ordered SQL processing by directory structure
Introduce deterministic processing for SQL files based on a predefined directory order (`ORDERED_DIRS`) to ensure execution respects dependencies. The remaining directories are processed alphabetically to handle any additional structures. This change enhances safety and predictability in SQL execution workflows.

Refactor db-easy structure and enhance functionality
Reorganized db-easy modules: extracted constants, restructured adapter implementations, and added missing dependencies. Updated package metadata and scripts for clarity. These changes improve modularity, maintainability, and functionality of the library.
